sections.title: Getting started
paragraphs: Start by defining your purpose (work, study, family, retirement, investment) and timeline. Then identify the correct visa pathway, gather required documents, and confirm local registration steps after arrival.
Requirements depend on your nationality and purpose of stay. Short visits may be visa‑free for some nationalities, while long‑term stays typically require a visa or residence authorization.
Timelines vary by visa type and documentation readiness. Plan for several weeks to a few months, plus time to gather documents, translations, and apostilles where required.

sections.title: Visas and residency
paragraphs: Common pathways include work visas, student visas, family reunification, retirement, digital nomad, and investment-based residence. Each has specific eligibility criteria.
No. Working on a tourist visa is not permitted. You must hold a visa or residence authorization that allows work.
Most work visas require an employer sponsor and a job offer. Some specialized or independent activity categories may have different requirements.
Paths vary, but may include time in status, family ties, or other criteria. Keep records of lawful residence and follow local renewal timelines.

sections.title: Documents and legalization
paragraphs: Typically: valid passport, application forms, proof of income or support, police clearance, proof of address, and purpose‑specific documents (job offer, enrollment, marriage certificate).
Many documents must be apostilled in the issuing country and translated into Portuguese by a certified translator in Brazil. Verify exact requirements for your case.
Some documents (like police clearances) have short validity windows. Plan document timing to avoid expiration.

sections.title: Arrival and registration
paragraphs: The CPF is Brazil’s tax ID. It’s required for banking, rentals, utilities, mobile plans, and many services.
Yes, most long‑term visas require registration after arrival. Deadlines apply, so book appointments promptly.

sections.title: Cost of living and budgeting
paragraphs: Costs vary widely by city and lifestyle. Major metros are more expensive than smaller cities. Build a realistic monthly budget for rent, utilities, food, transport, and healthcare.
Many visa categories and rentals require proof of income or financial means. Requirements depend on the visa type and local policies.

sections.title: Housing
paragraphs: Some landlords request a guarantor or proof of income. Short‑term rentals are easier while you establish local documents.
Most newcomers rent first. Buying can be considered after you understand neighborhoods, costs, and legal requirements.

sections.title: Healthcare
paragraphs: Public healthcare is available, but coverage and wait times vary. Many residents supplement with private health plans.
Costs depend on age, coverage, and city. Compare plans carefully and confirm network coverage near your location.

sections.title: Work and taxes
paragraphs: Remote work may be permitted under specific visa categories. Ensure you meet the requirements and understand tax obligations.
Tax residency depends on length of stay and other factors. Consult a tax professional to understand your obligations.

sections.title: Education and family
paragraphs: Yes. Public and private schools are available, but enrollment requirements vary by location and school type.
Many visas allow dependents, but requirements differ. Confirm eligibility and document needs for each family member.

sections.title: Safety, language, and culture
paragraphs: Portuguese helps with daily life and official processes. In major cities, you may find English support, but basic Portuguese is strongly recommended.
Safety varies by city and neighborhood. Use local guidance, avoid risky areas, and follow common‑sense precautions.

sections.title: Practical setup
paragraphs: Most banks require a CPF and proof of address. Digital banks may have simpler onboarding for newcomers.
Prepaid SIMs are available at airports, malls, and carrier stores. A CPF is often required for activation.

sections.title: Legal and compliance
paragraphs: Federal rules are consistent, but local procedures and appointment availability vary. Always confirm with local offices.
Complex cases benefit from professional guidance. Ensure any provider is reputable and transparent about fees.

sections.title: Still have questions?
paragraphs: Use the contact page to describe your situation, timeline, and destination city. We will point you to the right resources.
